Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Story: My phone buzzes insistently as I sit on the edge of the bed, my girlfriend’s voice still echoing in my ears from our argument. She’s in the other room, waiting for me to come back and talk things through, to prove that I care enough to fight for us. But the screen lights up with my mom’s name—our weekly call, the one I promised never to miss. I know she’s waiting to hear about my week, to tell me about Dad’s new hobby and ask if I’m eating well. I can almost hear her gentle disappointment if I don’t pick up. My girlfriend’s muffled sobs drift through the door, and my heart twists. I want to be the son who never lets his parents down, who keeps them close even from miles away. But I also want to be the boyfriend who doesn’t walk away when things get hard. The phone keeps ringing, and I stare at it, torn between two worlds, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing down on me.
